title: Linklaters on brink of electing first female senior partner
text:
Law firm Linklaters is set to elect a female senior partner for the first time in its 183-year history, in the latest example of more women breaking into the top ranks of commercial law. 

Linklaters, one of the City's “magic circle” firms, is about to conclude elections to replace outgoing senior partner and deals lawyer, Charlie Jacobs, with three women in the running. 

The candidates are global corporate head Aedamar Comiskey — tipped as the frontrunner by two insiders — London corporate and M&A partner Sarah Wiggins; and Milan-based western Europe managing partner, Claudia Parzani. Corporate partner Tom Shropshire was an early candidate but left the firm last week to become general counsel at Diageo.

The all-female shortlist is unusual for a City law firm but follows other recent examples of women breaking into top jobs in the historically fusty legal sector.

These include 45-year-old Georgia Dawson, who was elected head of Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer in September, and corporate lawyer Rebecca Maslen-Stannage, who was named Herbert Smith Freehills' new senior partner in March. 

One Linklaters insider called the election of a female leader a “historic” moment. “These are all seasoned operators in their own right but this will be meaningful,” she said. “A lot of young women will draw inspiration from this.”

Insiders said changing the firm's remuneration system was at the top of the agenda during the election campaign, which comes at a crucial point for the firm. Linklaters has come under increased pressure from highly-profitable US rivals seeking to poach its best talent, and has struggled to crack the US market, the world's largest and most lucrative. 

Several firms have been forced to abandon “lockstep” remuneration models, which tie pay to time served, to compete with pay offers from US firms, including Linklaters' rival Allen & Overy. 

One Linklaters partner said: “[The pay structure] needs to change. We need to be able to compete for talent in a way we currently can't.”

But he added: “It's something people have really strong feelings around and it's very difficult to get people to change their view.” 

Linklaters' new senior partner will replace Jacobs when he leaves to join JPMorgan as co-head of investment banking later this year. The South African lawyer is among the City's top advisers and will depart from Linklaters after more than three decades. 

Linklaters will kick off elections to replace current managing partner Gideon Moore next year. The banking partner won a second term in 2019 for three years and will step down in April 2022.
